intro: Quercus longicaudata, commonly known as the long-tailed oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, elongated acorns and dark green, lobed leaves that turn reddish in the fall. The tree typically grows to a height of 20–40 feet and has a narrow, upright form. Its bark is smooth and gray when young, becoming fissured with age. This species is often found in moist, well-drained soils in forested areas.
